commit_message:
Add cross-pod L2 Networking spec file

1. What is the problem?
In the Tricircle, the cross pod L2 networking automation is
established after the VM is plugged into. The simplest way to
stretch one L2 network across multiple OpenStack instances is to
use a same VLAN network, but there is a lot of limitation: the
number of VLAN segment is limited, the VLAN network itself is not
good to spread across multiple sites, although you can use some
gateways to do so. But there are so many tenants in the cloud, and
new tenants could be added into the cloud dynamically, fixed physical
network configuration for dynamic tenant networking is hard to manage.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
To deal with the above problem, flexible tenant level L2 networking
automation across multiple OpenStack instances in one site or in
multiple sites is needed in the Tricirlce.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle to
realize the solution?
To implement the features that networking automation supports more
than one bottom pod in AZ or multiple AZs for different use cases
in the Tricircle

Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tricircle/+spec/cross-site-connectivity
Change-Id: I616048c13d03f48aa16d9ff48572b0d5a49d6fb4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/40/304540/25 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =================================== Tricircle cross pod L2 networking =================================== Problem description =================== Currently,the ``Tricircle`` just supports the cross-pod L3 networking and one network in top pod can only locate in one bottom pod,tenant network is bound to bottom pod.Otherwise we cannot correctly configure extra route since for one destination ``CIDR``,we have more than one possible nexthop addresses. The scenarios of cross-pod L2 networking can be divided into three types, ``shared VLAN``, ``shared VxLan`` and ``mixed VLAN/VxLan``.for shared VLAN type ,network in each bottom OpenStack is VLAN type and has the same VLAN ID.For shared VxLAN type,network in each bottom OpenStack is VxLAN type and has the same VxLan ID.For mixed VLAN/VxLAN type,network in each bottom OpenStack may have different types or have different segmentation ID. To achieve cross-pod L2 networking,L2GW will be used to connect L2 network in differnt pods.No extra route is required to connect L2 network.ALL L3 traffic will be forwarded to the local L2 network,then go to the server in another pod via the L2GW. Use Cases ========= **Use case for shared VLAN:** A user create network Net1,plugin check the configuration,if ``tenant_network_type`` equals shared_vlan,it will invoke shared vlan dirver. Shared VLAN driver will allocate ``segment``,and assgin ``network_type`` with vlan,and update network with ``segment`` and ``network_type`` to DB. A user create VM1 in AZ1,and connect to network Net1.If vm will be booted in POD1,tricircle will send create network message to POD1.Create network message includes ``network_type`` and ``segment``. Then user create VM2 in AZ2,and connect to network Net1.If vm will be booted in POD2,``tricircle``(``Nova-APIGW`` need to get the network info)will send create network message to POD2.Create network message includes ``network_type`` and ``segment``. **Use case for different VLAN:** A user create network Net1,plugin check the configuration,if ``tenant_network_type`` equals multi_vlan,it will invoke multi vlan driver. Multi vlan dirver need to do nothing(if segment is allocated in bottom). A user create VM1 in AZ1,and connect to the network Net1,the VM is booted in bottom POD1,and ``Nova-APIGW`` create network in POD1,then ``Nova-APIGW`` query the network detail information(using admin role),and get network type,segment id,the ``Nova-APIGW`` update the segment infomation to ``Neutron``,call ``neutron`` update network with the new segment information. Then the user create another VM2,and with az info AZ2,then the VM should be booted in bottom pod2 which is located in AZ2,And when VM2 should be booted in AZ2,``Nova-APIGW`` also create a network in pod2,and query the network information including segment and network type,update this new segment to the network in ``Neutron``. Proposed change =============== Difference between L2 networking for tenant's VM and for L3 bridging network: * A special bridge network is create and connect the routers in different bottom OpenStack.We configure the extra routes of the routers to route the packets from one OpenStack to another.In current implementation,we create this special bridge network in each bottom OpenStack with the same ``VLAN ID``,so we have a L2 network to connect the routers. * The creation of bridge network is triggered when attaching router interface and adding router external gateway. * The L2 network for VM is triggered by ``Nova-APIGW`` when a VM is to be created in one pod, and find that there is no network there, then the network will be created before the VM is booted, for VM booting needs parameter network or port. * The IP/Mac for VM is allocated in the ``Tricircle``, top layer to avoid IP/mac collision if allocate them seperately in bottom pods. Pluggable L2 networking framework: * Because ``tricircle`` top do not use ``ml2`` mechanism, so we can use it for L2 networking accross openstack. We need to implement different type driver. * Frist, config ``tenant_network_types = shared_vlan`` for ex, ``vlan_range=1-3000``. * Second, when tenant create network, ``Tricircle plugin`` invoke the corresponding type driver, like ``Shared_vlan_Driver``. And driver allocates segment and assign ``network_type`` with vlan, update the info to DB. * When create vm, if top needs to send create network to bottom, it send message inclueds ``network_type = vlan``, ``physical_network = p1``, ``segmentation = vlan 1`` to bottom. Data model impact ----------------- In database, we are considering setting physical_network in top OpenStack as ``bottom_physical_network#bottom_pod_id`` to distinguish segmentation information in different bottom OpenStack. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== When admin user creates network, he/she specifies the network type as one of the network type discussed above. In the phase of creating network in top OpenStack, only one record is saved in the database, no network will be created in bottom OpenStack. When user uses the network created by admin (how about tenant created network) to boot a VM, Nova API gateway checks the network type. For shared VLAN and shared VxLAN network, Nova API gateway directly uses the segmentation ID allocated by top Neutron to create network in bottom OpenStack. For mxied VLAN/VxLAN network, Nova API gateway first creates network in bottom OpenStack without specifying network type and segmentation ID, then update the top network with bottom network segmenation information returned by bottom OpenStack. `Neutron multi-segment network API`_ allows us to create virtual L2 networks made up of multiple segments with different details, so we can associate a top network with segmentation information in different bottom OpenStack. In database, Network Segment model has the following fields: ``network_id``, ``network_type``,``physical_network``,``is_dynamic`` and ``segment_index``, we are considering setting physical_network in top OpenStack as ``bottom_physical_network#bottom_pod_id`` to distinguish segmentation information in different bottom OpenStack. Segmentation information is passed to drivers to handle different scenarios. .. _`Neutron multi-segment network API`: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/ml2-multi-segment-api Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Other contributors: Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

subject: Fix stable/mitaka gate failures

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-15 13:26:32.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas/commit/9a3d1bc7d767e7277653ba64c956ea1901b1af2a', 'message': "Refactor gate hooks

The aim of this change is to make gate_hook and post_test_hook
more generic and prepare base for adding a new functional job
and tests. The patch also includes a number cosmetic changes
which should make the hooks' code easier to read.

- Moved all argument parsing to decode_args.sh.
- gate_hook: Extracted code related to configuring Octavia into a
  separate function.
- post_test_hook: Filling test_subset is not required if the aim
  is to run all set (api-* job).
- post_test_hook: Don't set OS_TEST_PATH and OS_TESTR_CONCURRENCY
  as it's also done in tox.ini.
- Style fixes.

Depends-On: Ib5e34f67209394eff43da7e5b5f722f4888deb0b

"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-06-15 15:35:08.000000000', 'files': ['neutron_lbaas/tests/contrib/decode_args.sh', 'neutron_lbaas/tests/tempest/v1/api/base.py', 'neutron_lbaas/tests/contrib/post_test_hook.sh', 'neutron_lbaas/tests/contrib/gate_hook.sh', 'neutron_lbaas/tests/tempest/v2/scenario/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron-lbaas/commit/c502db8400ee7cde42eb506623d7a818afaa3f02', 'message': "Fix stable/mitaka gate failures

This change is squashed from backports of
0b6a3fbdfab9768287205d278061a63204869e5d and
b68c0e27e3f52238dce048ead2538fdabe179e06. These two bugfixes
form a circular depencency and can't be merged without each
other.

The other way to solve this deadlock is to revert
https://review.openstack.org/322811 and
https://review.openstack.org/320998, merge
https://review.openstack.org/321563 and then start
anew.

Here are the commit messages of both changes:

Neutron-LBaaS: Fix network_resources path

* upstream tempest changed the namespace for
  network_resources, this change updates that path
* fixed changed deprecated config parameters
* replaced network_cilent passed into DeletableSubnet
  with subnets_client and routers_client

Refactor gate hooks

The aim of this change is to make gate_hook and post_test_hook
more generic and prepare base for adding a new functional job
and tests. The patch also includes a number cosmetic changes
which should make the hooks' code easier to read.

- Moved all argument parsing to decode_args.sh.
- gate_hook: Extracted code related to configuring Octavia into a
  separate function.
- post_test_hook: Filling test_subset is not required if the aim
  is to run all set (api-* job).
- post_test_hook: Don't set OS_TEST_PATH and OS_TESTR_CONCURRENCY
  as it's also done in tox.ini.
- Style fixes.

Change-Id: I32eaa12fb27a4cfbd09bd20e9821ebd310c32e44
Closes-Bug: #1581660
Closes-Bug: #1592564
Related-Bug: #1585116
"}]
commit_message:
Fix stable/mitaka gate failures

This change is squashed from backports of
0b6a3fbdfab9768287205d278061a63204869e5d and
b68c0e27e3f52238dce048ead2538fdabe179e06. These two bugfixes
form a circular depencency and can't be merged without each
other.

The other way to solve this deadlock is to revert
https://review.openstack.org/322811 and
https://review.openstack.org/320998, merge
https://review.openstack.org/321563 and then start
anew.

Here are the commit messages of both changes:

Neutron-LBaaS: Fix network_resources path

* upstream tempest changed the namespace for
  network_resources, this change updates that path
* fixed changed deprecated config parameters
* replaced network_cilent passed into DeletableSubnet
  with subnets_client and routers_client

Refactor gate hooks

The aim of this change is to make gate_hook and post_test_hook
more generic and prepare base for adding a new functional job
and tests. The patch also includes a number cosmetic changes
which should make the hooks' code easier to read.

- Moved all argument parsing to decode_args.sh.
- gate_hook: Extracted code related to configuring Octavia into a
  separate function.
- post_test_hook: Filling test_subset is not required if the aim
  is to run all set (api-* job).
- post_test_hook: Don't set OS_TEST_PATH and OS_TESTR_CONCURRENCY
  as it's also done in tox.ini.
- Style fixes.

Change-Id: I32eaa12fb27a4cfbd09bd20e9821ebd310c32e44
Closes-Bug: #1581660
Closes-Bug: #1592564
Related-Bug: #1585116

commit_message:
Implement OVO class init mechanism

This patch adds a mechanism to perform class initialization in Versioned
Objects.

One case where this is useful is when initializing the model class
attribute for all Persistent Versioned Objects.

We are currently trying to initialize the model class attribute for all
Versioned Objects in the registration hook, which is wrong on two
fronts, one is the place -it should be done in the
CinderPersistentObject- and the other is that we are doing it for all
classes -this could be easily fixed by checking if it's a
CinderPersistentObject class-.

This patch adds method `cinder_ovo_cls_init` to CinderPersistentObject
and changes the registration hook to call this method on any OVO class
that is registered if it exists.

Change-Id: I44c0fb41e3a2e6d615dc87ee6fe32d6a3ecf102a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/44/321144/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import inspect """Hook called when registering a class. This method takes care of adding the class to cinder.objects namespace. It also implements a per class initialization mechanism calling static method cinder_ovo_cls_init in the class and all its hierarchy classes. cinder_ovo_cls_init method should never call its superclass method, as this registration mechanism takes care of calling cinder_ovo_cls_init method for all base classes tree. """ # Build all init methods for all classes in the base tree init_methods = {supercls.cinder_ovo_cls_init for supercls in inspect.getmro(cls) if hasattr(supercls, 'cinder_ovo_cls_init')} for init_method in init_methods: init_method(cls) @staticmethod def cinder_ovo_cls_init(registering_cls): """This method is called on OVO registration and sets the DB model.""" # Persistent Versioned Objects Classes should have a DB model, and if # they don't, then we have a problem and we must raise an exception on # registration. try: registering_cls.model = db.get_model_for_versioned_object( registering_cls) except (ImportError, AttributeError): msg = _("Couldn't find ORM model for Persistent Versioned " "Object %s.") % registering_cls.obj_name() raise exception.ProgrammingError(reason=msg)
deleted_lines: # For Versioned Object Classes that have a model store the model in # a Class attribute named model try: cls.model = db.get_model_for_versioned_object(cls) except (ImportError, AttributeError): pass

commit_message:
Delete device when instance_id is null

When nfv delete action is performed, it helps to
remove the device from tacker when that device's
instance_id is null.

Closes-bug: #1588713
(cherry picked from commit c74cb38f23c9b7dd15a978d67a1c13f275349f48)

Change-Id: I3796a1c5b4a077d14c56ff84976e72a5a891fdca

commit_message:
Skip the gabbi-1.22.0

It seems the newest gabbi-1.22.0 support runing a test suite with multiple
workers, but the gabbi tests have sequence dependency. E.g. the
showAlarmState test depend on the updateAlarmState test.

Change-Id: I5b309f5df32f65ca490f5d7e8bd9371fbef5613d

commit_message:
Ironic agent kernel should be owned by user building image

The initramfs file created by the ironic-agent element is
owned by the user running disk-image-create; ensure that
the other files created by the element are also owned by
the user.

Change-Id: I829db5b8e8bf1fc68face9cd2bda52d2a5ccdd4f
Closes-Bug: 1593010

commit_message:
Add specification for dynamic pod binding

1. What is the problem?
In production clouds, each availability zone (AZ) is built by modularized
OpenStack instances. Each OpenStack instance acts as a pod. One AZ
consists of multiple pods. Among the pods within an AZ, they are
classified into different categories for different proposes, for instance,
general propose, CAD modeling and so on. Each tenant is bound to one pod,
where it creates various types of resources. However such a binding
relationship should be dynamic instead of static. For instance when
some resources in the pod are exhausted, tenant needs to be bound to a
new pod in same AZ.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
To deal with the above problem, the Tricircle dynamically bind tenants
to pod which has available resources. We call this feature dynamic pod
binding

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle to realize
the solution?
To realize dynamic pod binding, the following features need to be
implemented in the Tricircle.
1) To collect the usage in pod daily to evaluate whether the threshold
is reached or not.
2) To filter and weigh all the available pods for cloud tenants to bind
a tenant to a proper pod.
3) To manage and maintain all the active and historical binding
relationship.

This spec explains how Tricircle binds pods to tenants dynamically
in detail.

Blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/tricircle/+spec/dynamic-pod-binding

Change-Id: Ib429a59d3d216e578f9c451d84c1fe9a333cf050
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/24/306224/13 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ================================= Dynamic Pod Binding in Tricircle ================================= Background ======== Most public cloud infrastructure is built around Availability Zones (AZs). AZs consist of one or more discrete data centers, each with redundant power, networking and connectivity, housed in separate facilities. These AZs offer cloud tenants the ability to operate production applications and databases which are more highly available, fault tolerant and scalable than would be possible from a single data center. In production clouds, each AZ is built by modularized OpenStack, and each OpenStack is one pod. Moreover, one AZ can include multiple pods. Among the pods, they are classified into different categories. For example, servers in one pod are only for general purposes, and the other pods may be built for heavy load CAD modeling with GPU. So pods in one AZ could be divided into different groups. Different pod groups for different purposes, and the VM's pricing and performance are also different. Motivation ======== When creating a VM with volume attached in one pod, and if a new volume is created in another pod, the attachment will fail. The volume should be in the same pod where the VM is, otherwise the volume and VM is not able to finish the attachment if they are located in different pods. Hence, Tricircle needs to bind pods with tenants dynamically. The dynamic pod binding should be aware of the differences in cost. Solution: dynamic pod binding =========================== Tricircle needs to select a proper pod for a duration, in this duration VM and volume will be created for this tenant in the same pod. If this pod's resources exhausted or reach the limit for new resource provisioning. It's quite big challenge as more and more resources added to one pod, at last you will reach limitation, and it's quite notorious for capacity expansion inside one pod, you have to estimate, calculate, monitoring, simulate, test, online grey expansion for controller nodes and network nodeswhenever you add new machines to the pod. Hence, Tricircle needs to change the current pod binding for the tenant. For example, suppose we have two groups of pods, and each group has 3 pods, i.e. GroupA( Pod1, Pod2, Pod3) for general purpose VM GroupB(Pod4, Pod5, Pod6), Tenant1 is bound to Pod1, Pod4 during the first phase for several months. When detecting that there is no more resources in Pod1, Pod4, Tricircle needs to change the binding, for example, Tenant1 binding to Pod2, Pod5 If the tenant wants to allocate VM/volume for general VM, select Pod1. It can be implemented with flavor or volume type metadata. For general VM/Volume, no special tag in flavor volume meta_data. If the tenant wants to allocate VM/volume for CAD modeling VM, select Pod4, For CAD modeling VM/Volume, special tag "resource: CAD Modeling" in flavor volume meta_data If the tenant wants to allocate VM/volume for general VM, select Pod2, If the tenant wants to allocate VM/volume for CAD modeling VM, select Pod4, In the first phase, we can just add weight in Pod, for example, Pod1, weight 1, Pod2, weight2, this could be done by one new field in pod table, or no field at all, just link them by the order is created in Tricircle Implementation ============ Measurement --------- To get the information of resource utilization of pods, Tricircle needs to conduct some measurements on pods. For resources usages, currently cells provided interface to retrieve usage for cells [1]. If OpenStack is not running with cells mode, we can ask Nova to provide usage info in AZ show detail interface. Cinder also provide interface [2] to retrieve the backend pool usage. In bottom The statistic task should be done in bottom pod. But probably it may not be enough to manage resources properly using only above kinds of statistics coming from bottoms. On top There are also some functions of nova running on top of bottoms to manage, but they are not aimed at pods but for compute nodes. On top there is no heavy process. So calculation, or whatever processes to manage resources on top of bottom properly should run on top of us. Another API for usage query is at host level [3]. If the bottom returns the sum, it's also ok. But currently only one host detail information is returned. Tricircle ------- Tricircle needs a framework to support different binding policy, or say, binding filter. Each pod is one OpenStack instance, including controller nodes and compute nodes. E.g., +-> controller(s) - pod1 <--> compute nodes <---+ | The tricircle +-> controller(s) - pod2 <--> compute nodes <---+ resource migration, if necessary (resource controller) .... | +-> controller(s) - pod{N} <--> compute nodes <-+ Tricircle is to select which controllers the VM/Volume creation request should be forwarded to. Then the controllers in the selected pod will do its own scheduling. The simplest binding filter will be like this: line up all pods in each group, and always select the first pod, when all the resources in the pod has been allocated, remove it from the list. This is quite like what production cloud is built: first only few pods, and then add more and more pods if there is no enough resources in current cloud. List1 for general pool: Pod1 <- Pod2 <- Pod3 List2 for CAD modeling pool: Pod4 <- Pod5 <- Pod6 If Pod4's resource exhausted, the List1 changed to: Pod5 <- Pod6 If Pod1's resource exhausted, the List1 changed to: Pod2 <- Pod3. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= None Documentation Impact ==================== None Reference ======= [1] http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html#showCellCapacities [2] http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-blockstorage-v2.html#os-vol-pool-v2 [3] http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-compute-v2.1.html#showinfo

commit_message:
Use transport_url instead of oslo_messaging_rabbit

Aviod warning message:
oslo_config.cfg [-] Option "rabbit_hosts" from group "oslo_messaging_rabbit"
is deprecated for removal.  Its value may be silently ignored in the future.

Change-Id: Ibe591f104367e3c3e8d26c7a22be25cf53991599
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/84/328884/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: iniset $OCTAVIA_CONF DEFAULT transport_url $(get_transport_url)
deleted_lines: iniset $OCTAVIA_CONF oslo_messaging_rabbit rabbit_hosts ${RABBIT_HOST}:5672 iniset $OCTAVIA_CONF oslo_messaging_rabbit rabbit_userid ${RABBIT_USERID} iniset $OCTAVIA_CONF oslo_messaging_rabbit rabbit_password ${RABBIT_PASSWORD}

commit_message:
Remove heat.openstack.common.notifier supports

Remove backwards compatibility for heat.openstack.common.notifier.
We remove that feature since Juno and should be acceptable to drop
support in Newton.
Closes-Bug: 1592490

Change-Id: I6314b3c264cb2609c01063509a4700ca3108a34a

commit_message:
Fixed unit test for amphorae backend utils

In the function test_get_network_interface_file:
first we check path returned when 'agent_server_network_dir' is defined.

In the tested function the code of taking 'agent_server_network_dir'
is unreachable if there is a non-empty sting in 'agent_server_network_file'.
Hence, to test this case we should first set 'agent_server_network_file'
to None.

Change-Id: Ifb5951111585ee871e1956575d5434e09da8f8cf
Closes-Bug: 1585919
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/98/321398/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.CONF.set_override('agent_server_network_file', '', group='amphora_agent')

commit_message:
Ensure console-log is our last publisher

This is related to zuulv25, we make sure console-log is the last
publisher to ensure zuul-launcher logs are also uploaded.

This will be done over a series of commits to reduce the work load on
jenkins.

Change-Id: I426ec29e11a1636a58e3bd735e60c9240898649e
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

subject: Use manifest to backport OVOs during upgrades
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-18 10:26:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/9342b7e157f4863326846ec4522e746c779c4b67', 'message': "Add auto relationship mappings to VOs

To make objects that have other objects as fields compatible to an
earlier version, oslo versioned objects uses either a manifest passed to
obj_to_primitive or the object's obj_relationships mapping.

The obj_relationsips mapping is a dictionary where each related
versioned object (or list of version objects) has an interable with a
mapping, in the form of tuple, of this object's version to the related
object's version.

For example, if for Volume we could have.

 obj_relationships = {
     'snapshots': (('1.1', '1.0'), ('1.2', '1.1')),
     'volume_type': (('1.1', '1.0'),)
 }

Which tell us that for Volume version 1.1 it should use SnapshotList
v1.0 and VolumeType v1.0, and for Volume version 1.2 it should use
SnapshotList v1.1 and VolumeType v1.0.

This patch introduces a property that replaces standard Versioned Object
dictionary by the same name (obj_relationships) and dynamically builds
the relationships using existing object history stored in OBJ_VERSIONS.

Mapping will only be built once per class and this will only be used
during rolling upgrades when Oslo library accesses obj_relationships
attribute.

Instead of creating all possible mappings we only map when the related
object has changed, because oslo versioned object method
`_get_subobject_version` understand that even if we have changed our
version, the previous mapping with related object is still valid.  As
seen in above example for volume_type field.

This means that as long as we keep history in OBJ_VERSIONS right we will
not have to create and worry about keeping lists' child_versions field
or our versioned object's obj_relationships for fields with types
ListOfObjectsField and ObjectField.

Cloases-Bug: #1571566
Change-Id: Ibc1a1257830c925c10696c0b5aedd5f471c538d0

the relationships using existing object history stored in OBJ_VERSIONS.

Mapping will only be built once per class and this will only be used
during rolling upgrades when Oslo library accesses obj_relationships
attribute.

Instead of creating all possible mappings we only map when the related
object has changed, because oslo versioned object method
`_get_subobject_version` understand that even if we have changed our
version, the previous mapping with related object is still valid.  As
seen in above example for volume_type field.

This means that as long as we keep history in OBJ_VERSIONS right we will
not have to create and worry about keeping lists' child_versions field
or our versioned object's obj_relationships for fields with types
ListOfObjectsField and ObjectField.

Cloases-Bug: #1571566
Change-Id: Ibc1a1257830c925c10696c0b5aedd5f471c538d0
"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2016-05-19 11:14:46.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/daee3b09c23211ba5bd64da7f27fb620606fa580', 'message': "Add auto relationship mappings to VOs

To make objects that have other objects as fields compatible to an
earlier version, oslo versioned objects uses either a manifest passed to
obj_to_primitive or the object's obj_relationships mapping.

The obj_relationsips mapping is a dictionary where each related
versioned object (or list of version objects) has an interable with a
mapping, in the form of tuple, of this object's version to the related
object's version.

For example, if for Volume we could have.

 obj_relationships = {
     'snapshots': (('1.1', '1.0'), ('1.2', '1.1')),
     'volume_type': (('1.1', '1.0'),)
 }

Which tell us that for Volume version 1.1 it should use SnapshotList
v1.0 and VolumeType v1.0, and for Volume version 1.2 it should use
SnapshotList v1.1 and VolumeType v1.0.

This patch introduces a property that replaces standard Versioned Object
dictionary by the same name (obj_relationships) and dynamically builds
the relationships using existing object history stored in OBJ_VERSIONS.

Mapping will only be built once per class and this will only be used
during rolling upgrades when Oslo library accesses obj_relationships

not have to create and worry about keeping lists' child_versions field
or our versioned object's obj_relationships for fields with types

Cloases-Bug: #1571566

"}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2016-05-26 13:36:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/24b4c9cf5b3be4c68427b97bd19ac06cb7a9a93e', 'message': "Use manifest to backport OVOs during upgrades

To make objects that have other objects as fields compatible to an
earlier version, oslo versioned objects uses either a manifest passed to
obj_to_primitive or the object's obj_relationships mapping.

Which means that if we don't have any of those mechanisms in place our
rolling upgrades mechanism will fail whenever we try to backport a
Versioned Object that has set an ObjectField field because Oslo
Versioned Object will not know how to backport that related object.

This patch introduces the usage of manifests on backports when we are
doing rolling upgrades.

For the manifest we use the data in our Objects History.  Which means
that as long as we keep history in OBJ_VERSIONS right we will not have
to create and worry about keeping lists' child_versions field or our
versioned object's obj_relationships for fields with types
ListOfObjectsField and ObjectField.

commit_message:
Use manifest to backport OVOs during upgrades

To make objects that have other objects as fields compatible to an
earlier version, oslo versioned objects uses either a manifest passed to
obj_to_primitive or the object's obj_relationships mapping.

Which means that if we don't have any of those mechanisms in place our
rolling upgrades mechanism will fail whenever we try to backport a
Versioned Object that has set an ObjectField field because Oslo
Versioned Object will not know how to backport that related object.

This patch introduces the usage of manifests on backports when we are
doing rolling upgrades.

For the manifest, we use the data in our Objects History.  Which means
that as long as we keep history in OBJ_VERSIONS right we will not have
to create and worry about keeping lists' child_versions field or our
versioned object's obj_relationships for fields with types
ListOfObjectsField and ObjectField.

We also don't have to worry about cascade version bumping, as in
changing the List OVO version whenever the OVO it contains gets bumped,
or bumping our OVO whenever one of the related OVO fields is bumped.

Closes-Bug: #1571566
Change-Id: Ibc1a1257830c925c10696c0b5aedd5f471c538d0

subject: pkg: replace commands module with subprocess
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-26 15:45:30.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove/commit/54af193e99b68a0b817e606556536495ade2aec1', 'message': 'pkg: replace commands module with subprocess

The commands is deprecated since Python 2.6 and was removed from
Python 3. This change replaces it with subprocess. By the way, it
also changes the code to avoid a shell and so indirectly makes the
code safer (shell injections are no more possibles).

tox: run test_backupagent.py on Python 3.4.

Partially implements: blueprint trove-python3
Change-Id: I3818fa1498819cc77a3da42c12245c50b96cad59

commit_message:
pkg: replace commands module with subprocess

The commands is deprecated since Python 2.6 and was removed from
Python 3. This change replaces it with subprocess. By the way, it
also changes the code to avoid a shell and so indirectly makes the
code safer (shell injections are no more possibles).

tox: run test_backupagent and test_pkg on Python 3.4.

Partially implements: blueprint trove-python3
Change-Id: I3818fa1498819cc77a3da42c12245c50b96cad59

commit_message:
Fix Brcd zone driver initiator zone update

Modified the logic to do zoneadd or zoneremove to
modify the zone members when an initiator zone
is being modified instead of current logic which
deletes the zone and recreates it, in which time
the existing targets lose connectivity to the
initiator because of cfgdisable.

Change-Id: I24bc3d56aa36a9e39cff403f7447e359c760e732
Closes-Bug: #1563060

commit_message:
Extend microversion stuff to support resource classes

Current implementation of novaclient.api_versions.wraps allow to use
versioned methods for shell functions and resource managers. As resource
managers can have versioned methods, resource objects can have it too, but
it was not implemented yet. This patch fixes this omission.

Changes:
 - Add api_version property to base resource class. It is mapped to
   api_version property of manager class;
 - Move `novaclient.utils.generate_function_name` to
   `novaclient.api_versions._generate_function_name`, since this method is
   specific to microversion stuff and should not used outside api_versions
   module;
 - Rewrite _generate_function_name to handle class(owner) name. Previously,
   it was improssible to have two classes in one module with versioned
   methods with equal names.
 - Remove call of generate_function_name from novaclient.shell. Shell module
   should not take care about function identifiers. get_substitutions accepts
   object with __id__ property now.
 - Mark _add_substitution as private method, since it should not be used
   outside api_versions module
 - Split all versioned methods of Server resource from novaclient.v2.servers
   module.

Change-Id: Icfce16bfa6f919d7f8451d592f4a8e276b1f1709
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient refs/changes/48/308848/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @api_versions.wraps("2.0", "2.18") def update(self, name=None): """ Update the name and the description for this server. :param name: Update the server's name. :returns: :class:`Server` """ return self.manager.update(self, name=name) @api_versions.wraps("2.19") :param description: Update the server's description. @api_versions.wraps("2.0", "2.24") block_migration=False, value is False value None will be mapped to False. return self.manager.live_migrate(self, host, block_migration, disk_over_commit) @api_versions.wraps("2.25") def live_migrate(self, host=None, block_migration="auto"): """ Migrates a running instance to a new machine. :param host: destination host name. :param block_migration: if True, do block_migration, the default value is 'auto'. :returns: An instance of novaclient.base.TupleWithMeta """ return self.manager.live_migrate(self, host, block_migration) @api_versions.wraps("2.0", "2.13") def evacuate(self, host=None, on_shared_storage=True, password=None): on shared storage. return self.manager.evacuate(self, host, on_shared_storage, password) @api_versions.wraps("2.14") def evacuate(self, host=None, password=None): """ Evacuate an instance from failed host to specified host. :param host: Name of the target host :param password: string to set as admin password on the evacuated server. :returns: An instance of novaclient.base.TupleWithMeta """ return self.manager.evacuate(self, host, password)
deleted_lines: :param description: Update the server's description( allowed for 2.19-latest). if (description is not None and self.manager.api_version < api_versions.APIVersion("2.19")): raise exceptions.UnsupportedAttribute("description", "2.19") block_migration=None, value None will be mapped to False for 2.0 - 2.24, 'auto' for higher than 2.25 value None will be mapped to False. It will not be supported since 2.25 if (self.manager.api_version < api_versions.APIVersion("2.25")): # NOTE(eliqiao): We do this to keep old version api has same # default value if user don't pass these parameters when using # SDK if block_migration is None: block_migration = False if disk_over_commit is None: disk_over_commit = False return self.manager.live_migrate(self, host, block_migration, disk_over_commit) else: if block_migration is None: block_migration = 'auto' if disk_over_commit is not None: raise ValueError("Setting 'disk_over_commit' argument is " "prohibited after microversion 2.25.") return self.manager.live_migrate(self, host, block_migration) def evacuate(self, host=None, on_shared_storage=None, password=None): on shared storage. After microversion 2.14, this parameter must have its default value of None. if api_versions.APIVersion("2.14") <= self.manager.api_version: if on_shared_storage is not None: raise ValueError("Setting 'on_shared_storage' argument is " "prohibited after microversion 2.14.") return self.manager.evacuate(self, host, password) else: # microversions 2.0 - 2.13 if on_shared_storage is None: on_shared_storage = True return self.manager.evacuate(self, host, on_shared_storage, password)

commit_message:
Add ServiceTopic & ServiceDisabledReason Enum

This change adds a new enum and field, ServiceTopicField
and ServiceDisabledReasonField, that will hold the constants for the
topic & disabled_reason field of the Service object. This enum
and field are based off the base oslo.versionedobjects enum and field.
This also changes over the service object to use the new field and bumps
the version so newer versions know to enforce valid values. Finally,
all uses of strings for comparison and assignment to this field are
changed over to use the constants defined within the enum.

commit_message:
3PAR: Fix delete volume when online clone

When an online clone volume is deleted, the clone needs to be stopped
first. On delete, a new exception is raised from the 3PAR. We need to
check for the error code when hpeexceptions.HTTPConflict is raised.

Change-Id: Iceb1b35e0312b109b2b19cd7d5c45b4a6242ccc5
Closes-Bug: #1349639

commit_message:
Make monasca-common pep8 compatible

Cleaned up test-requirements.txt in order to use the latest hacking
package.
Removed the ignored pep8 checks and made the code pass all of them.

Also removed the OpenStack Foundation copyright notice that was put
there accidentally before.

Change-Id: I3d287eb71fc2bf0e4d52856c11cbc8a347cac2ed

commit_message:
Adding content about running Lego session

Adding content about facilitating the hands on Lego session, with
suggestions for mentors.

Change-Id: Ia566a7c2817a004af47da62458e317594564ac8a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/training-guides refs/changes/20/325020/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Lego applied to Free Software contributions (15 min) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~These slides prepare students for the Lego activity, and ensure they understand the metaphors in use. The Lego in the exercise represents the code of a software project, in this case OpenStack. The students all take on roles that represent various facets of the OpenStack community, including upstream roles like Foundation and TCT, and contributors like corporations, and individual free agents. The group is split into their new 'teams' at this stage. Facilitators can choose any way they prefer to do this (selecting teams, or allowing students to self-select). The recommended numbers are in the slides, but can be changed to suit the number of participants in the room. For a very large group, consider separating into two 'communities', which then have to fit their streets together (use the metaphor of an API for this) to complete the session. Give each person a nametag to wear, with their first name and their role written on it. For free agents, don't disclose who is distracted, controversial, or agreeable. The community will need to work this out on their own.Ahead of time: ensure the existing Lego buildings are set out on a table, but not connected to each other. All the unsorted bricks should be available in several smaller boxes in a different part of the room, for participants to use. There is no need to display the boxes or instruction manuals. Once the students are separated into their new roles, and have an understanding of the project, begin the timer for the first sprint. During the five minutes planning time, encourage each group to get together and think about their project. If possible, give each group a corner of the room and access to a whiteboard or flipchart. For companies, ensure the CEO sets a direction, and the team are on board. For upstream, have them think about the community standards they want to set. Free agent contributors can get straight to work during this phase. Suggestions: * Companies: big industrial items like a shopping mall, carpark, energy plant, datacenter, hospital. * Free agents: community items items like vegetable patches, bicycle paths, public artworks, playgrounds. For the controversial agent, problematic items such as a jail, skate bowl, dog park. * Upstream: consider guidelines around consistency in the bricks used, how to connect the road and sidewalk between the buildings, the kinds of buildings they should request the community to make, and the things they simply will not accept. Start the timer for building time, and allow everyone to start work. During each building phase, have mentors wander around the groups listening in and making suggestions, without actually doing any of the work or giving answers. In your interactions with the students, do not be afraid to provoke some issues. For example, bring up the idea of an API (a way of connecting the buildings to each other) with individual companies, but don't mention it to upstream, so that upstream are finally faced with the challenge of standardizing the API. You could also, in the second or third sprint, encourage one group to call a midcycle to sort the problem out. During the final five minutes of the sprint (review time), ask everyone to take their hands off the Lego, and gather around the in-progress street. At this stage, upstream get to vote on the changes, and anything rejected gets sent back to the contributing group to be fixed. Ensure upstream give good reasons for rejections, along with suggestions for improvement. Encourage Upstream to reject a few things early on, to try and ensure contributors understand the need to have Foundation on board before they throw something over the wall. At the end of the four sprints, ensure you take a group photo!
deleted_lines: Agile for Contributors (15 min) ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~* Apply agile * Who is the customer? * Company & Upstream product owner * Sprint review presentation to UpstreamThe students make a virtual contribution simulation using Lego bricks as props, with the goal of expanding a Lego town, built by upstream. They are divided into teams; the teacher is by turns the product owner in the company and the upstream.

commit_message:
Match filter criteria when constructing URI for href based iteration

Without that, we compare apples to oranges (expected results excluding
shared networks and actual results including them).

Change-Id: Ia9b8b1e60acad54110a549da3b327820f2a1ec45
Closes-Bug: #1590116

commit_message:
Migrate keystone v2 images to v3 during Liberty upgrade

This fix migrates all Swift backed Glance image locations
from keystone v2 URLs to v3 in order to force the swift client
to make v3 API requests against keystone.
This migration is only necessary for the Kilo to Liberty migration
where the swift auth version has been set to v3.

Change-Id: I6fcc689dbd93d59bac20eaf19fc99d2705f1cb26
Closes-Bug: #1582279
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/70/317070/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - The Kilo upgrade playbook glance-db-storage-url-fix.yml to Liberty will migrate all existing Swift backed Glance images inside the image_locations database table from a Keystone v2 API URL to a v3 URL. This will force the Swift client to operate against a v3 Keystone URL. A backup of the old image_locations table is stored inside a new database table `image_locations_keystone_v3_mig_pre_liberty` and can be safely removed after a successfull upgrade to Liberty. This upgrade task is related to https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible/+bug/1582279

commit_message:
remove pacemaker constraints for nova services

Remove some Pacemaker constraints that should not be useful:

keystone-then-nova-consoleauth-constraint
Nova-consoleauth won't fail if keystone is not started.
The constrain was useless.

nova-consoleauth-then-nova-vncproxy-constraint and
nova-vncproxy-with-nova-consoleauth-colocation
Both services don't need ordering neither collocation, they can live in
separated nodes, I confirmed that with Nova folks.

nova-vncproxy-then-nova-api-constraint and
nova-api-with-nova-vncproxy-colocation
Nova API & Nova VNCproxy do not need to live together or need specific
ordering at all.

nova-api-then-nova-scheduler-constraint and
nova-scheduler-with-nova-api-colocation
Nova API and Nova Scheduler do not need to live together or need
specific ordering at all.

nova-scheduler-then-nova-conductor-constraint and
nova-conductor-with-nova-scheduler-colocation
Nova Conductor and Nova Scheduler do not need to live together or need
specific ordering at all.

Change-Id: Ife443f3c01276e8f218cf5fb11e705e86b49f9b9
Implements: ha-lightweight-architecture

commit_message:
Fix designate dns driver for SSL based endpoints

Allow setting options in designate section to specify if want
to skip SSL cert check. This makes it possible to work with HTTPS
based endpoints, the default behavior of keystoneclient is to always
set verify=True however in current code, one cannot either provide
a valid CA cert or skip the verification.

Change-Id: Ic2035e57b287b1173972f6c9e11739e69d2aaa84
Closes-Bug: #1588067

commit_message:
Add operator role to heat stack owner

The account used in SwiftResourcesTestJSON requires the heat stack
owner role along with the swift operator one. No pre-provisioned
account today satisifies that requirement, so fixing that.

Change-Id: I9db0154a364cec3214b5cabd8a7766a110c2b973

commit_message:
Fix post install jobs

The venv environment is used for post install jobs and thus cannot
currently use constraints, use an unconstraint install command for it.

Example failure:
http://logs.openstack.org/b8/b8a70e4aeca83ebefad4b127af71b1bd125efa40/post/zaqar-branch-tarball/d9fe983/

Change-Id: If6e9f85b3a8b15048453bf1177812fb37a8e2d54
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/30/330730/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # NOTE(jaegerandi): this target does not use constraints because # upstream infra does not yet support it. Once that's fixed, we can # drop the install_command. install_command = pip install -U --force-reinstall {opts} {packages}

directory, but let's move it with the others.

commit_message:
PoC Set rabbitmq_servers fact once

The purpose of this change is to speed up the integrated gate.
The first playbook of the deploy will need to sort the rabbitmq
servers and set the fact but subsequent playbooks can avoid that
work. This could save 5-10 minutes in the integrated gate right now.

The change should be very low impact for deployers. The facts cache
is well documented (currently under Troubleshooting). Secondly, the
existing trailing task to record the sorted servers as a fact is
updated to better expose the task's impact on cached facts. If a
deployer changes the rabbitmq servers in the deploy infrastructure
they will need to clear the cached facts or run without fact caching
as documented.

I can't find any other doc impacts right now but may have missed one.

Change-Id: I89d509f60fe3e2ec8f9b1b2140fb466f3414ede6

commit_message:
Use request object in auth plugins

Instead of passing the context_dict to our auth plugins pass the full
request and simplify the interfaces and plugin code to use these new
objects.

Change-Id: I9303a15be943e3b9759bed516a88aeae86282e2b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/90/330290/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def authenticate(self, request, auth_payload, auth_context): request.context_dict,
deleted_lines: def authenticate(self, context, auth_payload, auth_context): context,

commit_message:
Move cross domain/group/project auth tests

This commit moves a couple large/complicated tests from TestAuth to
TokenAPITests where they are tested with more token providers. This is an
effort to consolidate the token behavior tests into a single class.

Change-Id: I965b701ea900aaa83b7f11387962bfe64be21092
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/18/330218/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_user_and_group_roles_scoped_token(self): """Test correct roles are returned in scoped token. Test Plan: - Create a domain, with 1 project, 2 users (user1 and user2) and 2 groups (group1 and group2) - Make user1 a member of group1, user2 a member of group2 - Create 8 roles, assigning them to each of the 8 combinations of users/groups on domain/project - Get a project scoped token for user1, checking that the right two roles are returned (one directly assigned, one by virtue of group membership) - Repeat this for a domain scoped token - Make user1 also a member of group2 - Get another scoped token making sure the additional role shows up - User2 is just here as a spoiler, to make sure we don't get any roles uniquely assigned to it returned in any of our tokens """ domainA = unit.new_domain_ref() self.resource_api.create_domain(domainA['id'], domainA) projectA = unit.new_project_ref(domain_id=domainA['id']) self.resource_api.create_project(projectA['id'], projectA) user1 = unit.create_user(self.identity_api, domain_id=domainA['id']) user2 = unit.create_user(self.identity_api, domain_id=domainA['id']) group1 = unit.new_group_ref(domain_id=domainA['id']) group1 = self.identity_api.create_group(group1) group2 = unit.new_group_ref(domain_id=domainA['id']) group2 = self.identity_api.create_group(group2) self.identity_api.add_user_to_group(user1['id'], group1['id']) self.identity_api.add_user_to_group(user2['id'], group2['id']) # Now create all the roles and assign them role_list = [] for _ in range(8): role = unit.new_role_ref() self.role_api.create_role(role['id'], role) role_list.append(role) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[0]['id'], user_id=user1['id'], domain_id=domainA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[1]['id'], user_id=user1['id'], project_id=projectA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[2]['id'], user_id=user2['id'], domain_id=domainA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[3]['id'], user_id=user2['id'], project_id=projectA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[4]['id'], group_id=group1['id'], domain_id=domainA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[5]['id'], group_id=group1['id'], project_id=projectA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[6]['id'], group_id=group2['id'], domain_id=domainA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[7]['id'], group_id=group2['id'], project_id=projectA['id']) # First, get a project scoped token - which should # contain the direct user role and the one by virtue # of group membership auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=user1['id'], password=user1['password'], project_id=projectA['id']) r = self.v3_create_token(auth_data) token = self.assertValidScopedTokenResponse(r) roles_ids = [] for ref in token['roles']: roles_ids.append(ref['id']) self.assertEqual(2, len(token['roles'])) self.assertIn(role_list[1]['id'], roles_ids) self.assertIn(role_list[5]['id'], roles_ids) # Now the same thing for a domain scoped token auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=user1['id'], password=user1['password'], domain_id=domainA['id']) r = self.v3_create_token(auth_data) token = self.assertValidScopedTokenResponse(r) roles_ids = [] for ref in token['roles']: roles_ids.append(ref['id']) self.assertEqual(2, len(token['roles'])) self.assertIn(role_list[0]['id'], roles_ids) self.assertIn(role_list[4]['id'], roles_ids) # Finally, add user1 to the 2nd group, and get a new # scoped token - the extra role should now be included # by virtue of the 2nd group self.identity_api.add_user_to_group(user1['id'], group2['id']) auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=user1['id'], password=user1['password'], project_id=projectA['id']) r = self.v3_create_token(auth_data) token = self.assertValidScopedTokenResponse(r) roles_ids = [] for ref in token['roles']: roles_ids.append(ref['id']) self.assertEqual(3, len(token['roles'])) self.assertIn(role_list[1]['id'], roles_ids) self.assertIn(role_list[5]['id'], roles_ids) self.assertIn(role_list[7]['id'], roles_ids) def test_auth_token_cross_domain_group_and_project(self): """Verify getting a token in cross domain group/project roles.""" # create domain, project and group and grant roles to user domain1 = unit.new_domain_ref() self.resource_api.create_domain(domain1['id'], domain1) project1 = unit.new_project_ref(domain_id=domain1['id']) self.resource_api.create_project(project1['id'], project1) user_foo = unit.create_user(self.identity_api, domain_id=test_v3.DEFAULT_DOMAIN_ID) role_member = unit.new_role_ref() self.role_api.create_role(role_member['id'], role_member) role_admin = unit.new_role_ref() self.role_api.create_role(role_admin['id'], role_admin) role_foo_domain1 = unit.new_role_ref() self.role_api.create_role(role_foo_domain1['id'], role_foo_domain1) role_group_domain1 = unit.new_role_ref() self.role_api.create_role(role_group_domain1['id'], role_group_domain1) self.assignment_api.add_user_to_project(project1['id'], user_foo['id']) new_group = unit.new_group_ref(domain_id=domain1['id']) new_group = self.identity_api.create_group(new_group) self.identity_api.add_user_to_group(user_foo['id'], new_group['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant( user_id=user_foo['id'], project_id=project1['id'], role_id=role_member['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant( group_id=new_group['id'], project_id=project1['id'], role_id=role_admin['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant( user_id=user_foo['id'], domain_id=domain1['id'], role_id=role_foo_domain1['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant( group_id=new_group['id'], domain_id=domain1['id'], role_id=role_group_domain1['id']) # Get a scoped token for the project auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( username=user_foo['name'], user_domain_id=test_v3.DEFAULT_DOMAIN_ID, password=user_foo['password'], project_name=project1['name'], project_domain_id=domain1['id']) r = self.v3_create_token(auth_data) scoped_token = self.assertValidScopedTokenResponse(r) project = scoped_token["project"] roles_ids = [] for ref in scoped_token['roles']: roles_ids.append(ref['id']) self.assertEqual(project1['id'], project["id"]) self.assertIn(role_member['id'], roles_ids) self.assertIn(role_admin['id'], roles_ids) self.assertNotIn(role_foo_domain1['id'], roles_ids) self.assertNotIn(role_group_domain1['id'], roles_ids)
deleted_lines: def test_user_and_group_roles_scoped_token(self): """Test correct roles are returned in scoped token. Test Plan: - Create a domain, with 1 project, 2 users (user1 and user2) and 2 groups (group1 and group2) - Make user1 a member of group1, user2 a member of group2 - Create 8 roles, assigning them to each of the 8 combinations of users/groups on domain/project - Get a project scoped token for user1, checking that the right two roles are returned (one directly assigned, one by virtue of group membership) - Repeat this for a domain scoped token - Make user1 also a member of group2 - Get another scoped token making sure the additional role shows up - User2 is just here as a spoiler, to make sure we don't get any roles uniquely assigned to it returned in any of our tokens """ domainA = unit.new_domain_ref() self.resource_api.create_domain(domainA['id'], domainA) projectA = unit.new_project_ref(domain_id=domainA['id']) self.resource_api.create_project(projectA['id'], projectA) user1 = unit.create_user(self.identity_api, domain_id=domainA['id']) user2 = unit.create_user(self.identity_api, domain_id=domainA['id']) group1 = unit.new_group_ref(domain_id=domainA['id']) group1 = self.identity_api.create_group(group1) group2 = unit.new_group_ref(domain_id=domainA['id']) group2 = self.identity_api.create_group(group2) self.identity_api.add_user_to_group(user1['id'], group1['id']) self.identity_api.add_user_to_group(user2['id'], group2['id']) # Now create all the roles and assign them role_list = [] for _ in range(8): role = unit.new_role_ref() self.role_api.create_role(role['id'], role) role_list.append(role) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[0]['id'], user_id=user1['id'], domain_id=domainA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[1]['id'], user_id=user1['id'], project_id=projectA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[2]['id'], user_id=user2['id'], domain_id=domainA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[3]['id'], user_id=user2['id'], project_id=projectA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[4]['id'], group_id=group1['id'], domain_id=domainA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[5]['id'], group_id=group1['id'], project_id=projectA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[6]['id'], group_id=group2['id'], domain_id=domainA['id']) self.assignment_api.create_grant(role_list[7]['id'], group_id=group2['id'], project_id=projectA['id']) # First, get a project scoped token - which should # contain the direct user role and the one by virtue # of group membership auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=user1['id'], password=user1['password'], project_id=projectA['id']) r = self.v3_create_token(auth_data) token = self.assertValidScopedTokenResponse(r) roles_ids = [] for ref in token['roles']: roles_ids.append(ref['id']) self.assertEqual(2, len(token['roles'])) self.assertIn(role_list[1]['id'], roles_ids) self.assertIn(role_list[5]['id'], roles_ids) # Now the same thing for a domain scoped token auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=user1['id'], password=user1['password'], domain_id=domainA['id']) r = self.v3_create_token(auth_data) token = self.assertValidScopedTokenResponse(r) roles_ids = [] for ref in token['roles']: roles_ids.append(ref['id']) self.assertEqual(2, len(token['roles'])) self.assertIn(role_list[0]['id'], roles_ids) self.assertIn(role_list[4]['id'], roles_ids) # Finally, add user1 to the 2nd group, and get a new # scoped token - the extra role should now be included # by virtue of the 2nd group self.identity_api.add_user_to_group(user1['id'], group2['id']) auth_data = self.build_authentication_request( user_id=user1['id'], password=user1['password'], project_id=projectA['id']) r = self.v3_create_token(auth_data) token = self.assertValidScopedTokenResponse(r) roles_ids = [] for ref in token['roles']: roles_ids.append(ref['id']) self.assertEqual(3, len(token['roles'])) self.assertIn(role_list[1]['id'], roles_ids) self.assertIn(role_list[5]['id'], roles_ids) self.assertIn(role_list[7]['id'], roles_ids) def test_auth_token_cross_domain_group_and_project(self): """Verify getting a token in cross domain group/project roles.""" # added_lines: import binascii def test_iv_with_offset(self): # Test iv with offset > 0 and offset < 0 iv = self.crypto.create_iv() offset = [-1, 2] key = 'objL7wjV6L79Sfs4y7dy41273l0k6Wki' for val in offset: if offset < 0: with self.assertRaises(ValueError) as cm: self.crypto.create_decryption_ctxt(key, iv, offset) self.assertEqual("Offset must not be negative", cm.exception.message) elif offset > 0: ivl = long(binascii.hexlify(iv), 16) ivl += int(val / 16) + (1 << (16 * 8)) ivstr = format(ivl, 'x') iv = str(bytearray.fromhex(ivstr[(len(ivstr) - 2 * 16):])) dec_ctxt = self.crypto.create_decryption_ctxt(key, iv, 4) self.assertEqual(iv, dec_ctxt.iv)

commit_message:
Expose sample config opts for http-proxy-to-wsgi

Allow sample config generators to retrieve the options for the
http-proxy-to-wsgi middleware.

Change-Id: I862c9238b791098c9bb9ce4558db5b21dad14a30
Closes-Bug: #1590218
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.middleware refs/changes/82/326782/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'list_opts_cors', 'list_opts_http_proxy_to_wsgi',from oslo_middleware import http_proxy_to_wsgi list_opts_http_proxy_to_wsgi(), def list_opts_http_proxy_to_wsgi(): """Return a list of oslo.config options for the http_proxy_to_wsgi middleware. The returned list includes all oslo.config options which may be registered at runtime by the library. Each element of the list is a tuple. The first element is the name of the group under which the list of elements in the second element will be registered. A group name of None corresponds to the [DEFAULT] group in config files. This function is also discoverable via the 'oslo.middleware' entry point under the 'oslo.config.opts' namespace. The purpose of this is to allow tools like the Oslo sample config file generator to discover the options exposed to users by this library. :returns: a list of (group_name, opts) tuples """ return [ ('oslo_middleware', copy.deepcopy(http_proxy_to_wsgi.OPTS)), ]

commit_message:
Hotfix the issue with too new Firefox version

which Selenium WebDriver cannot connect to.

This commit squashes *two* commits, to be able to merge.
Both patches already landed in master.

Partial-Bug: 1590939
(cherry picked from commit 6f17650a3ac44fc112ce363473e520702a0eb8b5)

Fix port validator

A recent change in netutils now allows a port number 0
as valid port number. This made tests fail.

Closes-bug: #1592553
(cherry picked from commit 68ce548f8193e1b29475f1ed4d0d6c2506a1ffab)

Change-Id: Ide1de4638b9c8b3e0ec1d34f7c044e8a96cc5890
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/45/329145/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: set -x # install avconv to capture video of failed tests sudo apt-get install -y libav-tools && export AVCONV_INSTALLED=1 sudo wget -q -O firefox.deb https://sourceforge.net/projects/ubuntuzilla/files/mozilla/apt/pool/main/f/firefox-mozilla-build/firefox-mozilla-build_46.0.1-0ubuntu1_amd64.deb/download sudo apt-get -y purge firefox sudo dpkg -i firefox.deb sudo rm firefox.deb

commit_message:
Colocation make a group for pcmk nova resources.

This ensure that the entire nova-* service form a pacemaker group and
that somehow pacemaker doesn't try to restart services elsewhere.

Closes-bug: 1592776

Change-Id: I629db624f4179663696ffe8c80a567bf6d6b2e16

commit_message:
Skip network validation if explicitly requesting no networks

If we're explicitly told to not allocate networks when creating
servers there is no need to validate the network request from
the API, just skip it.

Part of blueprint get-me-a-network

Change-Id: I21466fbe74e1f483923090327f73af0432b5ad4d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/02/309602/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: validate = True if requested_networks is not None: validate = not requested_networks.no_allocate if validate: return self.network_api.validate_networks( context, requested_networks, max_count) # If the network request was specifically 'none' meaning don't allocate # any networks, we just return the number of requested instances since # quotas don't change at all. return max_count
deleted_lines: if requested_networks is not None: return self.network_api.validate_networks(context, requested_networks, max_count)

commit_message:
No need for 'default=None' in config variable

By default the value is None. There is no need to specify
this.

Change-Id: Iffb9dcaad366330e1bad3a3a0e707bb833953c08

commit_message:
Fix alembic migration on MySQL 5.7

Presently, attempting to run alembic migrations for Octavia on a host
using MySQL 5.7 as the database back-end fails with an error about a
nullable field in a primary key. This commit fixes the offending
migration and introduces a second, similar migration so that any
existing installation using MySQL 5.6 or older also have this field set
to be non-nullable.

Change-Id: Iae3d4f627c1124b1d913aab283e6e19d9c0f0dbb
Closes-Bug: #1590145

subject: Fix missing network object getattr
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-16 15:02:37.000000000', 'files': ['tempest/scenario/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/commit/efd3f4e706355b4cb44f596bce45dd688c44d3c3', 'message': "Fix missing network object getattr

In a recent commit we moved away from wrapping network responses in
those weird object wrappers during scenario tests. This greatly
cleaned up the code and made things more consistent. However, there
was 1 getattr that was missed. It wasn't caught in the gate because
this call path wasn't executed (although a 3rd party CI did hit it).

commit_message:
Fix missing network object getattr

In a recent commit we moved away from wrapping network responses in
those weird object wrappers during scenario tests. This greatly
cleaned up the code and made things more consistent. However, there
was 1 getattr that was missed. It wasn't caught in the gate because
this call path wasn't executed (although a 3rd party CI did hit it).
This shows the importance of testing and making sure we don't rely
too heavily on self verification. This commit corrects the oversight
and cleans up the last reference to the network object wrappers.

Change-Id: I1d221b12717cba68a4241c61d75c4f26c294a3a8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/31/330631/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ports.append({'port': port['id']})

commit_message:
Revert "Merge "Remove neutron OO wrappers""

This reverts commit 777a307b3c9f4284facf081e6b951b5755333adf, reversing
changes made to cf2150a534659964255a9682ecb32c7b78943ea6.

Change-Id: I80ff67cfd916b402ebbade0d643b5203cb9a4fe9

subject: Pin test-requirements to match OpenStack requirements
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-16 16:13:32.000000000', 'files': ['test-requirements.txt'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build/commit/0f83ce472836cc2fd2fe2a0cc8957f1a0f153eef', 'message': 'Pin test-requirements to match OpenStack requirements

A new release of flake8 is causing lint faiures. Stable branches
should have requirements pinned anyway.

This patch pins to the current stable/mitaka requirements from
the OpenStack requirements repository.

Change-Id: I3c0b2ee9125a44f075dbbbbf56f8758da4c7ae01
'}]
commit_message:
Pin test-requirements to match OpenStack requirements

A new release of flake8 is causing lint faiures. Stable branches
should have requirements pinned anyway.

This patch pins to the current stable/mitaka requirements from
the OpenStack requirements repository.

Change-Id: I3c0b2ee9125a44f075dbbbbf56f8758da4c7ae01
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-repo_build refs/changes/70/330670/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Move default stopping point to just before overcloud deploy
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-15 19:57:03.000000000', 'files': ['quickstart.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/commit/844cdd856b525cd739325fed14cffa0814d864ff', 'message': "Move default stopping point to just before overcloud deploy

For both the developer and new user use cases, there is rarely a
need to do anything before the undercloud is installed and images
and nodes are uploaded and registered. This patch moves up the
default stopping point to just before the overcloud deploy command
is run. This behavior is still changeable by changing the tags
passed to quickstart.sh.

Also fixes a small UI bug, where usage instructions get print out
even when not using quickstart's default playbook. These instructions
are unlikely to be accurate when used with a different playbook.

Change-Id: I40eb8560732f266a1cd4ac37187e5fbb9b620b8e
Closes-Bug: 1569477
"}]
commit_message:
Move default stopping point to just before overcloud deploy

For both the developer and new user use cases, there is rarely a
need to do anything before the undercloud is installed and images
and nodes are uploaded and registered. This patch moves up the
default stopping point to just before the overcloud deploy command
is run. This behavior is still changeable by changing the tags
passed to quickstart.sh.

Also fixes a small UI bug, where usage instructions get print out
even when not using quickstart's default playbook. These instructions
are unlikely to be accurate when used with a different playbook.

Change-Id: I40eb8560732f266a1cd4ac37187e5fbb9b620b8e
Closes-Bug: 1569477

commit_message:
nova-net: handle 'auto' network request in allocate_for_instance

This adds the check to the nova-network API allocate_for_instance
method such that if no network is allocated for the instance and
'auto' was requested, we raise an error.

Also, if 'auto' is requested, we pass requested_networks=None
to the network rpc api (and network manager) since a network
with uuid 'auto' isn't going to exist.

Similar handling is done for deallocate_for_instance.

Some of the unit tests for allocate had to be fixed to pass
a valid requested_networks value.

Part of blueprint get-me-a-network

Change-Id: I718e2b3312ddd9fab0808a585bdbefbb5419f901
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/06/297906/20 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.objects import network_request as net_req_obj @mock.patch('nova.network.rpcapi.NetworkAPI.allocate_for_instance') def test_allocate_for_instance_no_nets_no_auto(self, mock_rpc_alloc): # Tests that nothing fails if no networks are returned and auto # allocation wasn't requested. mock_rpc_alloc.return_value = [] instance = fake_instance.fake_instance_obj(self.context) nw_info = self.network_api.allocate_for_instance( self.context, instance, mock.sentinel.vpn, requested_networks=None) self.assertEqual(0, len(nw_info)) @mock.patch('nova.network.rpcapi.NetworkAPI.allocate_for_instance') def test_allocate_for_instance_no_nets_auto_allocate(self, mock_rpc_alloc): # Tests that we fail when no networks are allocated and auto-allocation # was requested. mock_rpc_alloc.return_value = [] instance = fake_instance.fake_instance_obj(self.context) self.assertRaises(exception.UnableToAutoAllocateNetwork, self.network_api.allocate_for_instance, self.context, instance, mock.sentinel.vpn, [(net_req_obj.NETWORK_ID_AUTO, None)])

subject: neutron: validate auto-allocate is available
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-22 19:50:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/624a9012e336bb19c90b136fd9871882d2bc3deb', 'message': "neutron: validate auto-allocate is available

This adds the auto-allocated-topology validation into
the neutron validate_networks path, which is called from
the compute API when creating instances.

If there are no available networks for the project and the
user specifically requested that a network be automatically
allocated for them (via the 'auto' network id on the request),
then we have to check that:

1. The auto-allocated-topology extension is available in neutron.
2. The dry-run validation for auto-allocated-topology passes.

Otherwise we fail the request with a 400 error. Since the
network API is raising a new type of exception, we have to handle
it in the REST API.

Part of blueprint get-me-a-network

Change-Id: Id174ddc6cd61b55f80ff2d55d5fc7b462ae144fd

commit_message:
neutron: validate auto-allocate is available

This adds the auto-allocated-topology validation into
the neutron validate_networks path, which is called from
the compute API when creating instances.

If there are no available networks for the project and the
user specifically requested that a network be automatically
allocated for them (via the 'auto' network id on the request),
then we have to check that:

1. The auto-allocated-topology extension is available in neutron.
2. The dry-run validation for auto-allocated-topology passes.

Otherwise we fail the request with a 409 error. Since the
network API is raising a new type of exception, we have to handle
it in the REST API.

Part of blueprint get-me-a-network

Change-Id: Id174ddc6cd61b55f80ff2d55d5fc7b462ae144fd

commit_message:
Tox: Remove exclude directories that no longer exist

Remove directories that no longer exist in the project,
for example openstack/common. This is now part of libraries
that are imported.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I5e8abb022686c581e5faa8063b7497582122cc3e

commit_message:
Pin test-requirements to match OpenStack requirements

A new release of flake8 is causing lint faiures. Stable branches
should have requirements pinned anyway.

This patch pins to the current stable/mitaka requirements from
the OpenStack requirements repository.

Change-Id: I1cf0fd0ecec6aab216834d7adb56cb32e27c9677
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-security refs/changes/89/330689/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
return global control of force_cached_image

this change re-introduces the ability to set `force_cached_image`
globally, while still allowing it to be set per-image.  This makes it
possible to control this behavior without having to re-define the
entire "images" list.

Change-Id: I9a10a076b95d6f83ac70d354fadeec5188bf6e82
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/66/330166/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - include: fetch_image.yml vars: image: "{{ item }}"

commit_message:
make --requirements cumulative

this change makes the --requirements option behave more like
--extra-vars: you can specify it multiple times, and all files will be
passed to the 'pip install' command.  That is, if you run:

    quickstart.sh --requirements extra.txt --requirements more.txt ...

You will get:

    pip install -r requirements.txt -r extra.txt -r more.txt

Note that `requirements.txt` is always included (or rather, the file
specified in `OOOQ_BASE_REQUIREMENTS`).

Change-Id: I6d2fd7923bc7555791a582cf1a10a1e792374470
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-quickstart refs/changes/86/330086/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: : ${OOOQ_BASE_REQUIREMENTS:=requirements.txt} pip install --no-cache-dir "${OPT_REQARGS[@]}" || pip install "${OPT_REQARGS[@]}"OPT_REQARGS=("-r" "$OOOQ_BASE_REQUIREMENTS") OPT_REQARGS+=("-r") OPT_REQARGS+=("$2")

commit_message:
Add upgrade_levels section to nova.conf if it is missing

When no [upgrade_levels] section present in nova.conf file,
fuel-octane should add it and set the upgrade levels. Otherwise,
live migration is not possible for rolling upgrade scenario.

Change-Id: I60e5f88beab3c5da039885522b17355cedde7582
Closes-bug: 1583596
(cherry picked from commit 816c83eb36d6b94eb4f0602a62bf45684e31fc78)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-octane refs/changes/09/330609/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: add_upgrade_levels = True in_section = False for line in old: if line.startswith("[upgrade_levels]"): add_upgrade_levels = False in_section = True new.write(line) continue if in_section and line.startswith("["): in_section = False if in_section and line.startswith("compute="): LOG.warning( "Skipping line so not to duplicate compute " "upgrade level setting: %s" % line.rstrip()) continue new.write(line) if add_upgrade_levels: new.write("[upgrade_levels]\ncompute={0}\n".format(version))
deleted_lines: for line in old: new.write(line) if line.startswith("[upgrade_levels]"):

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-16 16:41:02.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/keystone/commit/5ec7c98ad4663df026f99e27fe7b1b6cd369f9c2', 'message': "Use upper-constraints for cover job

The coverage job wasn't using upper-constraints because of a
supposed issue in infra. The issue only affects jobs that run in
the post queue, but keystone's cover job runs in the regular gate
queue, so the problem doesn't affect us.

By using upper-constraints, we can avoid having the job fail when
library releases have problems.

Change-Id: I8808da3e7c1263f3685f0e8b64055e0e7f2d0294
Closes-Bug: 1587239
"}]
commit_message:
Use upper-constraints for cover job

The coverage job wasn't using upper-constraints because of a
supposed issue in infra. The issue only affects jobs that run in
the post queue, but keystone's cover job runs in the regular gate
queue, so the problem doesn't affect us.

By using upper-constraints, we can avoid having the job fail when
library releases have problems.

Change-Id: I8808da3e7c1263f3685f0e8b64055e0e7f2d0294
Closes-Bug: 1587239

commit_message:
profiles/nova/pacemaker/consoleauth: add missing require

When moving the service from THT to puppet-tripleo, I missed this
requirement. So nova-consoleauth will only start when openstack-core
resource is actually ready.

Change-Id: Id3da8b19be1cdc381a0ef3b7de94ec06fd2a3e95
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/69/330669/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

Change-Id: I3e6091eb2bc221a16fdc18b998ba138058818894
